title: New croc sighting in Sungai Semenyih - Nation | The Star Online
text:
KLANG: Another crocodile was spotted, this time in Sungai Semenyih in Selangor.
Selangor Wildlife and National Parks Department (Perhilitan) director Abd Rahim Othman said the public had tipped off the department about seeing the crocodile in the river earlier in the week.
"We saw the crocodile in a swampy area near the Semenyih river," said Abd Rahim, dismissing the possibility of this crocodile being the same one sighted in Sungai Klang on Tuesday.
Abd Rahim said the crocodiles would be left on their own in the river "if they are not in danger of being harmed or if there is no possibility of them causing harm."
Zoo Negara assistant curator Herman Bernard said the reptile would remain alone at the deep end of the river if it was left undisturbed.
“Usually if a crocodile is alone, it would hardly come up because lone crocodiles don’t like attention,’’ he said.
The crocodile, believed to be the saltwater variety (Crocodylus Porosus), was spotted Tuesday near the Kota Bridge here.
A video showing the two-metre crocodile swimming along the river went viral on social media.
According to Herman, crocodiles will attack only when they are in the water.
“They don’t attack when they are on land and cannot run much as well,’’ he said.
He said the crocodile could have swum up the river to where it was spotted.
“But Klang is also known to have had a lot of crocodiles before the post-independence period when there wasn’t much development in the area,’’ he added.
The saltwater crocodile is not an endangered species and is farmed for its skin.
Herman said the best solution for now would be for the authorities to relocate the crocodile as it is not known whether there is sufficient food for it in the river.
If food is insufficient, the crocodile may surface and this will not be safe for anglers.
“You never know what to expect from an animal and so the best solution would be to relocate the crocodile,’’ Herman said.
Former Zoo Negara assistant director and chief veterinarian Datuk Dr S. Vellayan said the crocodile could have escaped from a farm or was dumped into the river by its owner.
“It could also have escaped and washed into the river during the heavy downpour.
"There are also people who keep baby crocodiles as pets and another possibility is that it was dumped when they could not cope with it anymore,’’ said Dr Vellayan.
He added that if the crocodile had travelled to the spot on its own, it would either be with a partner or was in a pack.
Another possibility, said Dr Vellayan, could be that the crocodile was an alpha male which had left its group.
